title: How to write an essay to analyze a table - Quora

response.answer_text: Perhaps “Analysis” or “Analyze” is not the actual word to describe your assignment. “Describe” (verb) or “Description” (noun) is more likely what you are seeking. Of the Four Modes of Discourse (Exposition, Descritption, Narration, Argument referred to as EDNA (a woman’s name) Description is the writing mode that requires the use of Adjectives. What you might do first is do an internet search for adjectives like Adjectives + List: However, you are probably going to need more than just a vocabulary list. What you will need is some guidance about “How to write a descriptive essay”. So one free website that I found which has some instruction both in adjectives and in writing Descriptive Essays is the following. Guide to Grammar and Writing Adjectives My personal thoughts are that I would describe the wood that the table is from. Knowing this can help get you started. For example: “The __________wood came from tree on a Malaysian hillside. It was taken by truck to a mill in _________________ and after examination by the mill expert in quality timber, it was decided that the ___________ wood should be cut into 5 centimeter thick planks that were 3 meters long. After cutting, the planks were stored in special shed where the wood as allowed to dry for a period of a year.” (I made all of this up of course, but it is just a suggestion about what might be done. What I did not do was use any of the suggested Adjectives from a website. That is something that a person must learn to do.) What can help is for you to ask a basic question about any object you describe. Ask: “What is the essential characteristic (thing, fact, aspect) of this object?” Regarding the legs of the table, a writer might think about the workman who cut the wood, or the kind of saw or saw blade used, and how is the wood treated? Is the wood cut and immediately sold? Is it dried or treated with a chemical? What kind of a tradesman built the table? Was the table built and sent to a “showroom” where tables are sold? How much was the original timber sold for by the people who cut the tree. How much did the lumber mill sell the planks for? What did the tradesman charge for building the table from the raw lumber? …and on and on…and on.  To be honest with you, I do not like Descriptive Writing and I do not care a lot about Adjectives when the subject is studying English or writing. The reason is that the most important part of English is the Verbs, and the verb Nominalizations (noun forms of verbs) and more than that, the Mental Verbs (called Stative Verbs) Most people trying to practice “writing,” cannot even communicate their feelings or ideas with any effectiveness. How can they effectively describe an object such as a “table”. List of Adjective Words “Your Dictionary” is another good free place to find a list of Adjectives. You can find many such websites.  Another thing that might help with writing your descriptive essay would be to find all of the Synonyms for “wood” and “board” and “plank” and “beam”. Also, you may want to do another Internet search using these words: “descriptive writing exercises”.  What may be helpful for you to know is that the Four Modes of Discourse are not an exclusive system. Sometimes, something written will show all Four Modes of Discourse. They can blend together and this can be confusing, when one thinks about writing description and then discovers argumentation, narration, and exposition have become part of what has been written. Mark Twain was one of the great writers of Description. You can find his essay “Life On The Mississippi” on the Internet for free. He was masterful in his description. (Personally, I “respect” Description, but I do not “like” it. It emphasizes the use of Adjectives, and this complicates the learning process and the writing process for those who are studying the English Language for school and academic purposes.  I suppose a  person  might  prefer a  mild  “description”  of a  mundane object (which a table is) over  “exposition” or “argumentation” as an early writing project.)
